subject: Add Volume ACL Permissions: DB
commit_message:
Add Volume ACL Permissions: DB

ACL implementation brings a mechanism of access permission management into
Cinder project. Currently there is only one type of volume access permission,
which is full access(The user can do any operations on the volume.).
If a volume is created by a user, it grants all access of this user and
the users with super authorizations, like administrators.
With ACL implementation, it is possible for different users to have different
levels of volume access permissions. ACL can differentiate users in terms of
granting different access permissions to volumes, which can establish
a foudation for sharing volumes, transferring volumes,
attaching multiple VM to a volume, etc.

Access permissions:

The owner of the volume and the administrators always have the full
access.
The owner, the administrators and the users with Read permission --
can read the permission of the volume.
The owner, the administrators and  the users with Write permission --
can edit the permission of the volume.
The owner and the administrators -- can give the volume access permission
to a group of users, users in a tenant, all users.
The user can check his own access permission to a specific volume.
The permissions of the administrators are unable to edit by any other user.
The permission of the creator can be modified by administrators only.

Access permission represents as an integer, which bits are mapped to:
1st (less significant) bit -- Read/Only attach;
2nd -- Read/Write attach;
3rd -- View Permissions;
4th -- Edit Permissions;
etc.

Where

Read: the user can only read the volume, including reading the content
	of the volume, the volume properties and the volume metadata.
Write: the user can read and write the volume. The user can do any operations
	on this volume, including all the API operations.
Permission Read: the user can read the permission list for this volume and
	be able to see who can access this volume with which permission level.
Permission Write: the user can read and edit the permission list for
	this volume and be able to see and edit who can access this volume
	with which permission level.

Implementation:

Part 1. DB
    Add a new table called VolumeACLPermission with columns:
    id - the primary key of the row;
    volume_id - indicates volume's ID;
    entity_id - indicates group or project ID which the permission
    affects or '*' keyword for everyone;
    type - "project" means entity_id is project_id; "group" means
    entity_id is group_id;
    access_permission - indicates access permission level. (as
    described in Access Permission above)

    Use cases:
    * The owner(user_id1) grants Read access to everyone. The
    corresponding record:
        {id: 2, volume_id: 'volume_id1', entity_id: '*', type:
        'project', access_permission: 1}
    * The owner(user_id1) grants Read+Permission Read access to all the users
    in a group(group_id1). The corresponding record:
        {id: 3, volume_id: 'volume_id1', entity_id: 'group_id1', type:
        'group', access_permission: 5}

blueprint volume-acl

Change-Id: I5e64247ff38c060a2278b3718205834d306f5028

subject: Fix migration 185 to work with old fkey names
commit_message:
Fix migration 185 to work with old fkey names

Due to different versions of MySQL it is possible to end up with
different FK's then what is expected. For example the FK constraint
on instance_info_caches changed from instance_info_caches_ibfk_1
to instance_info_caches_instance_uuid_fkey and on virtual_interfaces
from virtual_interfaces_ibfk_1 to
virtual_interfaces_instance_uuid_fkey meaning databases who have
upgraded from before folsom may have the old fkey.

This patch adds a check for those with the old fkey name to make sure
it is dropped before changing unique constraints (as is required by
MySQL). It also fixes the fkey name to be as defined in 133 if it
wasn't before (which will persist on downgrade being consistent with
those who have come in after folsom).

Closes-Bug: #1245502

subject: make rbd usable for ephemeral storage
commit_message:
make rbd usable for ephemeral storage

Currently when using rbd as an image backend, nova downloads the
glance image to local disk and then copies it again into rbd.  This
can be very slow for large images, and wastes bandwidth as well as
disk space.

When the glance image is stored in the same ceph cluster, the data is
being pulled out and pushed back in unnecessarily. Instead, create a
copy-on-write clone of the image. This is a fast, and does not depend
on the size of the image. Instead of taking minutes, booting takes
seconds, and is not limited by the disk copy.

Add a direct_fetch() method to the image backend, so backends
like rbd can make optimizations like this. Try to use direct_fetch()
for the root disk when it comes from an image, but fall back to
fetch_to_raw() if direct_fetch() fails.

The majority of this code was taken from the cinder rbd driver.
The only new parts are the direct_fetch() method for the image
backend, and the small backwards-compatible interfaces changes
needed to make use of it.

Closes-Bug: 1226351

subject: Add AllocatedCapacityWeigher
commit_message:
Add AllocatedCapacityWeigher

AllocatedCapacityWeigher is a weigher that weigh hosts by their
allocated capacity. The main purpose of this weigher is to simulate
the SimpleScheduler's behavior, which sorts hosts by the size of
all volumes on them.  So by allocated capacity, it equals to the
sum of size of all volumes on target host.

In order to keep track of 'allocated' capacity, host state is updated
to add a 'allocated_capacity_gb' attribute to record the value, which
means each back-end must report one extra stats to scheduler.
Fortunately, the 'allocated' capacity we are interested in here is
pure Cinder level capacity, the volume manager can take all the burden
to calculate this value without having to query back-ends. The volume
manager does the initial calculation in init_host() by the time when it
has to query all existing volumes from DB for ensure_export(). After
initial calculation, volume manager/scheduler will keep track of every
new request that changes 'allocated_capacity' and make sure this value
is up to date.

!DriverImpact! Cinder driver developers, please read on:

This patch contains a change that might IMPACT volume drivers: volume
manager now uses 'stats' attribute to save 'allocated_capacity_gb'.
And this information will be merged with those stats drivers provide
as a whole for scheduler to consume.  If you plan to report any form
of allocated space other than the apparent Cinder level value, (e.g.
actual capacity allocated), Please choose a key name other than
'allocated_capacity_gb', otherwise it will *OVERWRITE* the value volume
manager has calculated and confuse scheduler.

Partially implements bp: deprecate-chance-and-simple-schedulers
